newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft, techs to lead Wall St higher.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft, techs to lead Wall St higher.

text.p: A rally in high technology issues on better-than-forecast Microsoft Corp earnings is expected to lead Wall Street stocks higher at the start of trading on Friday.
The Dow industrials slipped to a modest loss yesterday as a powerful three-day rally in blue chips appeared to have run out of steam, at least for the time being.
"There isn't any economic news out today, but there's good news concerning Microsoft. It should take techs up again," said Westfalia Investments chief strategist Peter Cardillo.

"I suspect that we will probably have a positive session for most of the day, with some selling possible later," Cardillo said. "Earnings reports are positive and there is no economic data. A stable bond market should give us some support in early trading."
Larry Wachtel, analyst at Prudential Securities, said that high techs will remain a vital part of the market, but that strength will be selective.
"Networkers are in a downward phase and chipmakers are in an upward phase. The techs got pretty beat up and will probably be helped by Microsoft today," he said.

In Tokyo, the Nikkei Average climbed 258.73 points, or 1.43 percent, to end at 18,352.14. Raw material issues such as steel and chemicals backed by firm earnings continued to attract investors. A rebound in long-strapped financial issues also helped the index.
In London, the FTSE 100 index fell 2.8 to 4296.1.

Microsoft Corp was the standout in London trading of U.S. stocks after the software giant reported better-than-expected earnings following the market close Thursday. Microsoft was trading at 103-1/4, up from 100 in after-hours trading and up 5-1/8 from its New York close.
International Business Machines Corp was up 1/2 at 137-5/8, Texas Instruments Inc was up 1/2 at 58-1/4 and Digital Equipment Corp was up 1/2 at 27-3/4.
The dollar pared early losses against the yen in Tokyo and drifted against the mark and yen in Europe.
U.S. Treasuries were mixed, with the long bond down 5/32 to yield 7.08 percent.

The Wall Street Journal's Heard on the Street writes that cellular-phone pioneer Craig McCaw is boosting his stake in Nextel Communications. The paper asks if investors should start dialing in as well.
The New York Times Market Place writes that Bankers Trust New York Corp head Fred Newman is guiding a surprising turnaround of the company.
